askQuestion

public abstract void askQuestion(de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.FCAImplication<A> question)
Checks whether a given implication question holds. If yes, fires an expert action of type #CONFIRMED_QUESTION, if no an expert action of type #REJECTED_QUESTION and notifies listeners.

Specified by:
askQuestion in interface de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.Expert<A,I,O extends de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.FCAObject<A,I>>
Parameters:
question - the given implication question

counterExampleInvalid

public abstract void counterExampleInvalid(O counterExample,
                                           int reason)
Called to notify the expert that the specified counterexample is invalid due to the given reason. The reason is one of Expert.COUNTEREXAMPLE_EXISTS or Expert.COUNTEREXAMPLE_INVALID. An implementation of this method should then perform the necessary actions. For instance, if it is a human expert, it should display an error message with the reason.

Specified by:
counterExampleInvalid in interface de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.Expert<A,I,O extends de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.FCAObject<A,I>>
Parameters:
counterExample - the counterexample given by the expert
reason - the reason why the counterexample is not valid

forceToCounterExample

public abstract void forceToCounterExample(de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.FCAImplication<A> implication)
Requests a counterexample from the expert. Called in the case where accepting an implication would cause problems. In this case we do not ask the expert whether the implication holds, but tell him that accepting this implication will cause problems and request a counterexample directly using this method. Note that this can for instance occur while exploring DL ontologies due to anonymous ABox individuals. In a usual formal/partial context exploration, this case can not occur.

Specified by:
forceToCounterExample in interface de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.Expert<A,I,O extends de.tudresden.inf.tcs.fcaapi.FCAObject<A,I>>
